citation.article-title: Transfer of Thermobacteroides leptospartum and Clostridium thermolacticum as Clostridium stercorarium subsp. leptospartum subsp. thermolacticum subsp. nov., comb. nov. and C. stercorarium subsp. thermolacticum subsp. nov., comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Clostridium stercorarium (ster.cor.ar.i'um. L. adj. stercorarium pertaining to dung, referring to the source of the isolate, a compost heap)
The following description is based on the data of Madden (1983), Le Ruyet et al. (1985), Toda et al. (1988) and data presented in this paper.
Cells are rods (0.25-0.8x2-15 μm), and may be motile by peritrichous or single laterally inserted flagella.
The optimum temperature for growth is between 60 and 65 °C at pH 7.0-7.5.
Ferments cellulose, cellobiose, lactose, maltose, xylose and mannose but not mannitol, sorbitol, gelatin or casein.
Acetate, lactate, ethanol, H2, CO2 and small amounts of L-alanine are produced during glucose fermentation.
The G­+C content range of the DNA is 39-43 mol%.
Belongs to cluster III of the order Clostridiales, domain Bacteria.

The species is divided into three subspecies, Clostridium stercorarium subsp. stercorarium subsp. nov., comb. nov., Clostridium stercorarium subsp. thermolacticum subsp. nov., comb. nov. and Clostridium stercorarium subsp. leptospartum subsp. nov., comb. nov.
All three subspecies are isolated from compost.
The type species is Clostridium stercorarium and the type strain is NCIB 11754T.
